If engineer: beware the "org" you land. Makes a helluva lot of difference in your experience. Wlb, culture and otherwise (growth, pay, raises, promotions, mentorship opportunities, I can go on...)
Are there any specific orgs I should watch out for?

To try to get in or stay away? AMS, I've heard, is pretty bad you are on a phone call 70% of the time you're working. If you are a system engineer, you are very likely to not fall into AMS, haven't heard of a system engineer in AMS, all other orgs, depending on what your devs are doing + the budget your org has, should be pretty cool. If you are an SWE, you are very likely to be in either IP or Pop-health since CernerWorks and CTS have fewer devs than the former two, and there is of course the chance that you might end up in AMS. Both IP and Pop-health are pretty good. You are more likely to get a better pay raise (compared to CernerWorks or CTS, these orgs are pretty broke almost all the time) and waaaaaayyyy much better wlb than the other orgs I mentioned above.

It's a decent place to start and get a grip on any specific tech stack. You get to save money because of the low cost of living. There's no bonus. Only annual raises which the average person gets about 3%.Culture is good. People are nice. On campus facilities such as gym, swimming pool and clinic are a plus.

Cerner pays around ~70k for entry level swe. Half of Cerner based in KC is support oriented. So I'd say if you are being recruited for any 3 of the 6 larger "orgs" in Cerner, be prepared for talking to code-illeterate people over Skype calls for hours and hours debugging(that too, I hear, not all the time) pretty s*itty legacy code. I hear that in those teams, you actually barely get to even see code. And you never write any code at all. But on the other side, some, I say "some" teams work on pretty cool stuff. My team is pretty cool though. So, before you come in, (and of course, if you have other choices) ask about what exactly you will be doing in your day-to-day.Other facts: Cerner's annual pay raise is capped at 2.3%(or 2.7, either way, if you join at 70k, your raise will be ~1800, which is still peanuts) for "highly valued" associates. Cerner does not pay bonuses. Cerner does not offer stock options.
Thank you!

Percentages will vary for a given rating somewhat year-to-year. I've received a number of outstanding ratings over the years, and have had raises from 7% to 14% as a result. The last time I was reviewed as highly valued the raise was 5%.. so just FYI, it is not always the same, and not the same access business units.

My salary at Cerner when I first joined, as a Software Engineer, was $75k in 2012,  I had about 2 years of experience at time of joining. When I left the company in Feb this year, as a Senior Software Engineer, my salary was $95k.

This place will give you ample opportunity to learn corporate lifestyle, politics, diplomacy at workplace. If you are not confident enough to be able to go to an interview that is for a product based company (product based companies, that are actively developing stuff, Cerner is also a product based company but it's been a while that Cerner made something new, which makes Cerner more of a service seller than a product seller,  usually have a higher bar for hiring) come join Cerner, learn what you need to get ready for the big market. In exchange for the opportunity you were provided with by Cerner, you part with some of your time, (for peanuts) and do some maintenance work on the software. Since PP is stopped for now, regular transfers usually gets processed much faster, anywhere between 3-4 months vs usual 6-8 months. Meanwhile you can stay with your current employer and keep looking for better offers if you wish.

I cannot guarantee anything, but it's the pattern. Premium processing though faster is known to clog the system pushing the processing times for regular petitions. In it's absence,  regular petitions will be processed in the order they were filed. Basically no one would jump in the queue for a while.

I got placed on a 2-week pip and beat it to buy more time. They decided to put me on another one but a slightly more relaxed one. I'm working on finding another job on the side in the meantime.

If a manager likes you the manager would not put you on a PIP unless you were truly fucking up. The fact that you beat the PIP is proof that you are a performer. Putting people on PIPs is no way to help an employee to improve. I guess the manager did not have the patience to coach you and instead opted to try and get rid of you. A PIP invariably damages the relationship between the employee and the manager. I wouldn't use your manager as a reference in the job hunt

Makes sense. I guess for me I'm a little wary because I value my work-life balance.

Don't fret on it, keep working and increasing your work experience with different companies until you find your right match ( company which will accept you on behalf of your strengths and will provide you the wlb). Not necessarily. You can switch at any time. But here's the trick. An Approved I-140 ensures the date that the PERM was applied as the "Priority Date". If you switch within 180 days from the date of I-140 Approval, employers have the authority to revoke the GC process thus far, so Priority Date is lost. Switching after 180 days of I-140 Approval helps with "porting" the said "Priority Date" with the new employer's GC process. About paying the employer, well that's between you and your employer, most Consulting Companies have that arrangement with their employees, while Full Time Employment does not even bring in such an arrangement.

@cernkc1. The day your Labor Application (PERM) was filed is your priority date. This is transferable if and only if you have an I-140 approved for 180 days before you switch jobs.2. Your current employer revoking the I-140 has no bearing on anything.3. Your new employer will only start your GC process in 3-6 months. For them to get to I-140 will take about 8-12 months from when they start.4. Last thing to consider is if you are hitting your 6 year limit on H1B. If so, in order to get further extensions, you need to have an I-140 approved.

Will have to file for GC again, assuming you are in the backlog.In new company, RSU‚Äôs usually don‚Äôt vest until 1 year, it‚Äôs called as 1 year cliff. New company if they pay for your relocation, may make you pay it back if you leave early, usually a year is what they choose.Old company may charge you for immigration. It depends on your agreement and if they enforce it. By law they can‚Äôt charge you for H-1B or PERM, only I-140 I believe and that too if you signed an agreement.

Yea when you switch you can use your old I-140 for H1B extensions with any employer but can‚Äôt use it with new employer to file I-485 if priority date is current, need the new employer to do PERM and I-140 again.Assuming you have I-140 with old employer, they can ask you to pay back immigration costs related to I-140 but not for costs related to PERM and H1B. It‚Äôs if you singed an agreement with them.
